fields.description:
In Crowd, it is possible to define a collection of groups a newly created user will be a member of, at a per-directory level:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Automatically+Assigning+New+Users+to+Groups

We would like to offer a similar feature in the common UI plugin, however, we do not need to provide a full-blown group picker. We can just expose a text field that allows the user to enter a comma-delimited list of group names that exist in the directory.

Along with the UI work, we'll need to be able to implement the actual logic that performs the auto group add. In Crowd, this is done by an event listener plugin. We can try drop the plugin into JIRA/Confluence and see if it will work - otherwise we will need to pull up the logic in the actual directory implementation.

The auto-group-add functionality only needs to be exposed to the UI on:
- Delegated LDAP with auto user add (not when auto user add is disabled)
- Read-write and read-only with local groups (not with read-only)
fields.summary: Implement group membership add on first auth

fields.description:
Currently there is no drop down to select the type of directory you'd like to integrate delegated authentication LDAP with in the Admin UI Plugin:

https://skitch.com/shihabske/rk4gm/configure-ldap-user-directory-jdog-jira-team-dogfood

Crowd does offer this option, and also pre-populates fields based on the selected directory type:

https://skitch.com/shihabske/rk4gf/configuring-a-delegated-authentication-directory-crowd-2.1-atlassian-documentation-confluence

The UI Plugin does implement a similar feature, but only for full LDAP directories. Perhaps we can borrow or share some of that code to implement this.
fields.summary: Allow directory type selection in the delegated authentication directory in EMBCWD plugin

fields.description:
Currently, the Admin UI Plugin allows the creation of delegated authentication directories that simply delegate the authentication to the LDAP server, but do nothing else.

https://skitch.com/shihabske/rk4fu/configure-ldap-user-directory-jdog-jira-team-dogfood

In Crowd, delegated authentication directories copy the user on auth. It would be good if the Admin UI Plugin allows an option to copy the user on auth (just a flag - perhaps checkbox or radio button on the UI). This will then set the attribute {{ATTRIBUTE_CREATE_USER_ON_AUTH}} to {{true}}/{{false}}. The underlying logic to perform the actual copy-on-auth is already implemented.

The other part of this UI task is to show/hide extra properties required to implement copy-on-auth. In particular, when "copy on auth" is first selected, we will need to allow the user to enter in values for the:
- user display name attribute
- user first name attribtue
- .. etc 
ie. ALL of the User related attributes, NONE of the group related ones

See the Crowd documentation for an _idea_ of what attributes we should be displaying: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+a+Delegated+Authentication+Directory

We can copy the UI elements from the UI Plugin Screen to create a full LDAP directory (so that the UI looks consistent).

https://skitch.com/shihabske/rk4f6/configure-ldap-user-directory-jdog-jira-team-dogfood
fields.summary: Allow copy on auth in the delegated authentication directory in EMBCWD plugin
Embedded UI Plugin needs to support delegated authentication directories properly

fields.description: See https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/EMBCWD-696
fields.summary: Embedded UI Plugin does not merge existing attributes when updating the directory

fields.description:
- Add an application in Crowd.
- Add a directory to the application
- Go to the Permissions tab
- Click Cancel

*Expected:* Reload the Permissions tab with the state prior to any edits

*Actual:* There is no Action mapped for namespace /console/secure/application and action name view (see attachment for full stack trace)
fields.summary: Error when clicking Cancel on the "Permissions" tab when adding/updating an application.

fields.description: Crowd has minor dependencies on Java 6. Fix them to support JDK 1.5 and set up a continuous integration build to catch future regressions.
fields.summary: Crowd does not build against JDK 1.5

fields.description:
Currently Crowd allows admins to use the email field as the user name for authentication. However, keeping this same configuration would not allow Admins to edit LDAP User entries, as their LDAP servers still expect a User Name to be added to the User Name Attribute and the Email to be added to the Email Attribute.

It would be good to allow Crowd to point to different attributes in different use cases.

For this specific example:

*Authentication*:
Crowd User Name Attribute -> Email LDAP Attribute

*Add/Edit User*
Crowd User Name Attribute -> User Name LDAP Attribute
fields.summary: Allow LDAP Connectors to use different attributes depending on the use case

fields.description:
During one installation, we recognized that some of the usernames in AD contained unicode characters. After synchronization of the connector directory, Crowd stalled. It was not possible to remove the directory since Crowd was trying to synchronize the directory in the background. I had to remove the directory manually from the DB. We modified the user names and resolved the problem. Although this problem occured due to inappropriate user names and not linked directly to Crowd, It would be nice to add a control for this kind of user names and let Crowd go on working.

Some more information about the problem:
- Crowd synchronizes for the first time
- Everything seem fine
- But any operation is not possible, each time a user is selected, Crowd tries to resynch and starts raising errors in the log.
- The reason for the log is Crowd tries to re-insert the problematic users to the cwd_users table and UQ constraint is violated.

You can see the problem in the attached log on line 386 for example
fields.summary: Nonstandard user name causes unstabilityin Crowd

fields.description: The user DN password is persisted to local database without encryption. One of our costomers takes this as a security problem. Is it possible to persist the password with encryption?
fields.summary: LDAP directory user DN password

fields.description:
With regards to http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+a+Delegated+Authentication+Directory, we need to:
* Update the 3 existing screenshots so that the fifth "Options" tab is shown
* Link to http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Automatically+Assigning+New+Users+to+Groups - basically describe the auto-membership-adding-on-successful-auth feature.

We may need to update screenshots on the other directory connectors too.
fields.summary: Update screenshots for Options tab on Directory configuration screens to highlight the auto-membership-add feature

fields.description:
When ApplicationServiceGeneric tries to remove a User from a Group, it loops over all directories and tries to remove the membership from each directory in turn and swallows any errors along the way, even though it knows the directory the user belongs to.

Removing groups from groups has similar issues.
fields.summary: ApplicationServiceGeneric swallows errors when removing Users from Groups

fields.description:
- Add an LDAP directory to Crowd
- Go to the groups tab and add a new Group to the LDAP directory that was just added.

*Expected:* Group to be created and propagated to LDAP server
*Actual:* Error occurs

Note: I can add groups directly from applications that use Crowd Server as their directory and that action propagates fine to LDAP server. 

{code}
[LDAP: error code 21 - INVALID_ATTRIBUTE_SYNTAX: failed for Add Request : 
ClientEntry dn: cn=crowdgroup, ou=groups,ou=system objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames uniqueMember: uid=admin,ou=system cn: crowdgroup description: : 
ERR_280 Attribute value {0} for attribute {1} is syntactically incorrect]; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.InvalidAttributeValueException: 
[LDAP: error code 21 - INVALID_ATTRIBUTE_SYNTAX: failed for Add Request : ClientEntry dn: cn=crowdgroup, ou=groups,ou=system objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames uniqueMember: uid=admin,ou=system cn: crowdgroup description: : ERR_280 Attribute value {0} for attribute {1} is syntactically incorrect]; remaining name 'cn=crowdgroup, ou=groups,ou=system' 
{code}
fields.summary: Unable to add groups to LDAP directory through crowd UI

fields.summary: XML Backup fails if user attributes are empty or NULL

fields.description: When adding a new application, the client should be able to tell the REST server to append the current request's remote address to the list of allowed IP addresses. The REST service will then append the remote addresses to the list specified in the body of the request.
fields.summary: Application Management REST API should have option to add the address of the current HTTP request

fields.description:
{{ApplicationService.isUserAuthorised(Application application, String username)}} checks if the user belongs to a authenticating group for the application. Extract this functionality from ApplicationService to a separate class/interface.

Clean up includes removing the {{CachingApplicationService}} class, and providing a no-cache implementation of the user authorisation class for JIRA and Confluence to use.
Change will break JIRA and Confluence when they upgrade to the next milestone.
fields.summary: Split out User Authorisation code from ApplicationService to a separate class

fields.description:
CWD-2171 has introduced a new page to allow selection of source directories when the import operation is performed on crowdified apps. The page only has been manually tested. It would be better if we can have Selenium of something that tests the UI functionality.

Please note that as of the time this issue was created, it is not clear whether the new page will be needed as other Atlassian Apps (Jira, and Conf) do not support multiple internal directories just yet.
fields.summary: UI test for import functionality from other Atlassian apps

fields.description:
Similar to [CWD-2175|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2175] except adding UAL to the process as well.

We can start work on this issue when Confluence have a milestone that can create a bi-directional link to JIRA (manually).

We will need to verify that app link creation is possible in the setup process, after the JAACS link has been established. We only need to verify that the link exists and is present in both the JIRA and Confluence admin screens. We do not need to verify that the app link is useable for transferring data (eg. jira-issues-macro) as that work is Confluence's plate.
fields.summary: Verify that it's possible to connect Confluence to JAACS using UAL in Confluence's setup process

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 

This is inefficient, and happens to be causing problems for multi-tenancy in JIRA.  It should be caching the module that it instantiated when enabled() was called, and using that to disable.
fields.summary: PasswordEncoderModuleDescriptor.disabled() reinstantiates the password encoder module

fields.description: We have an optimisation in our hibernate-backed Directory and Application code where instead of replacing the attributes, we update the existing collection (using {{retainAll}}). This assumes that the collection field is mutable. Since we can't just create a immutable copy of what's passed in {{setAttributes}}, we need to ensure that all usages of {{setAttributes}} are passing in an immutable copy.
fields.summary: Hibernate Backed Classes should not have immutable collections passed in
Rename and move LdapPermissionOption to embedded-crowd-api

fields.description:
Test syncing with 10 directories, each consisting of 3k users from AD (can be the same OU in AD, just 10 logical directories in Crowd).

Also test syncing concurrently with large requests like findAllGroupRelationships.
fields.summary: Create a load test for concurrently synchronising multiple directories

fields.description:
It should be possible to disable nested groups on the RemoteCrowdDirectory, so that queries are faster to execute.

This does not mean that the server does not support nested groups, it just means that the client will not perform any nesting resolution and will return empty collections when searching for group members/memberships of a group.
fields.summary: Allow nested groups to be disabled in the RemoteCrowdDirectory

fields.description:
The REST client accepts certain connection configuration properties such as:
* connection timeouts
* connection pool size
* proxy with optional auth details

It should be possible to read these from Directory attributes and pass them through to the underlying CrowdRestClient in the RemoteCrowdDirectory.

The intention of this improvement is to allow the proxy/connection details to be configured via the UI in EMBCWD and potential for a Crowd-Crowd connector.
fields.summary: Allow RemoteCrowdDirectory to pass in the connection properties for the underlying CrowdRestClient

fields.description:
By looking at Advanced Settings it seems that the following are the default timeouts:

Read Timeout (seconds): 120s
Search Timeout (seconds): 60s
Connection Timeout (seconds): 0 (Value of 0 means the TCP network timeout will be used, which may be several minutes.)

Such a high connection timeout makes the "Test Settings" button on Add directory really annoying if you get your settings wrong.

I suggest a much lower setting like maybe 5s for each.
fields.summary: Default LDAP timeouts are set too high

fields.description:
The old Crowd integration libraries supported a timeout configuration to avoid hanging request threads in the applications when Crowd didn't respond in a timely fashion.

The new REST client should support the normal timeouts: connection and request, either by system properties or through configuration in the UI.

We need some kind of decision (either fixed or won't-fix) prior to 2.2, so I'll set the fix-for.
fields.summary: Support configuration of HTTP socket and request timeouts in REST client
CachingUserManager's implementation of checking whether a user exists or not given the username is not thread-safe and could return false if the cache is flushed in the meanwhile

fields.description:
A new administrator misconfigured the base dn of a delegated authentication directory (going to MS Active directory LDAP).  This prevented anyone from logging into crowd (or any application attached to crowd) in _any_ directory.  We have an internal directory for users who are crowd admins so that we can always log into crowd if ldap of something in the network fails.  In theory.  

Once you are locked out of Crowd you are sorta screwed.  I had to use pgadmin3 and whack the DB to fix the misconfig and restart crowd to restore access.
fields.summary: Exception in the delegated authentication directory prevents login to crowd
When removing a user then their alias names are not removed from database

fields.description: It can be quite confusing when this happens (especially if you don't know about the feature to turn nesting on/off) and it would be nice if there could be a warning or info in the logs about it.
fields.summary: Notify the admin in some way when nested groups exist in LDAP but won't be synced because nesting is off

fields.description: Display the sync status in JIRA/Confluence via the common UI plugin. There is an EMBCWD for this.
fields.summary: Add sync "status" feedback to common UI plugin

fields.description:
In Confluence, we get the following exception when trying to modify user information on a POSIX (read-only) LDAP server via Crowd:

{code}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: POSIX support is currently read-only
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.handleCommonExceptions(RestCrowdClient.java:1081)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.updateUser(RestCrowdClient.java:128)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RemoteCrowdDirectory.updateUser(RemoteCrowdDirectory.java:139)
{code}

As I see it, this method should throw OperationFailedException according to the RemoteDirectory and CrowdClient API documentation.

I think the fundamental problem here is the {{handleCommonExceptions()}} method in RestCrowdClient, which seems to throw IllegalArgumentException in quite a number of cases. None of the methods on the CrowdClient interface are documented as throwing IAE, so this exception therefore bubbles up to the unsuspecting client code and leads to unhandled exceptions.
fields.summary: RemoteCrowdDirectory.updateUser() can throw IllegalArgumentException

fields.description:
This task will require editing the Confluence setup UI to be configured during the setup process.

This is only to validate it's possible, not to create production-ready code. No automated tests.
fields.summary: Verify that it's possible to connect Confluence to JAACS in Confluence's setup process

fields.description: Although Confluence and Jira do not have UI to manipulate nested groups just yet, we will need to support them eventually.
fields.summary: Support nested groups in the Confluence/JIRA Importer

fields.description: There can be multiple directories per one installation of crowdified app. It is more sensible to allow users to select the source directory.
fields.summary: Allow users to choose source directory when import from crowdified Jira and Confluence
findUserWithAttributesByName of TranslatingApplicationService don't work correctly

fields.description:
Stacktrace snippet:
{code}
org.springframework.transaction.CannotCreateTransactionException: Could not create DirContext instance for transaction; nested exception is org.springframework.ldap.CommunicationException: crowd-ad1:389; nested exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: crowd-ad1:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused]
Caused by: org.springframework.ldap.CommunicationException: crowd-ad1:389; nested exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: crowd-ad1:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused]
Caused by: javax.naming.CommunicationException: crowd-ad1:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused]
	<snip>
	at javax.naming.ldap.InitialLdapContext.<init>(InitialLdapContext.java:134)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.support.LdapContextSource.getDirContextInstance(LdapContextSource.java:43)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.support.AbstractContextSource.createContext(AbstractContextSource.java:254)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.support.AbstractContextSource.getContext(AbstractContextSource.java:106)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.support.AbstractContextSource.getReadWriteContext(AbstractContextSource.java:138)
	at org.springframework.ldap.transaction.compensating.manager.ContextSourceTransactionManagerDelegate.getNewHolder(ContextSourceTransactionManagerDelegate.java:86)
	at org.springframework.transaction.compensating.support.AbstractCompensatingTransactionManagerDelegate.doBegin(AbstractCompensatingTransactionManagerDelegate.java:84)
	at org.springframework.ldap.transaction.compensating.manager.ContextSourceTransactionManager.doBegin(ContextSourceTransactionManager.java:126)
	at org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.getTransaction(AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.java:350)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.pageSearchResults(SpringLDAPConnector.java:283)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchEntitiesWithRequestControls(SpringLDAPConnector.java:384)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchEntities(SpringLDAPConnector.java:369)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.searchUserObjects(SpringLDAPConnector.java:565)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.findUserWithAttributesByName(SpringLDAPConnector.java:531)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.findUserByName(SpringLDAPConnector.java:518)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.authenticate(SpringLDAPConnector.java:968)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.performAuthenticationAndUpdateAttributes(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:131)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.authenticate(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:110)
{code}

The problem seems to be at line 384 of SpringLDAPConnector.searchEntitiesWithRequestControls() :
{code}
if (ldapPropertiesMapper.isPagedResultsControl())
{
    -->   CollectingNameClassPairCallbackHandler handler = pageSearchResults(baseDN, filter, contextMapper,
                    searchControls, ldapRequestControls, startIndex + maxResults);
     results = handler.getList();
}
{code}

The else block has a NamingException catch which converts it to an OperationFailedException but the if block doesn't catch the TransactionException.
fields.summary: SpringLDAPConnector doesn't throw OperationFailedException from CommunicationException when LDAP server connection refused
specifying an i18n resource file for a plugin does not work

fields.description:
Specially for large LDAP setups, Crowd will not be functional right after a restart if the LDAP data was not yet synched with the database. This will keep the integrated applications unavailable for a long time, waiting the sync to finish.

To avoid panic and the impression that the integration is not working, it would be great to have a Crowd [site-wide banner|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Adding+a+Site-Wide+Banner] informing that the sync is not finished and that the LDAP and Apps integrations cannot be tested yet.

Since this is a background operation that impacts all the system functionality, it deserves better communication for the the Admin.
fields.summary: Improve UI communication regarding LDAP data not yet synched with database cache

fields.description: crowd should host avatars, not individual apps
fields.summary: crowd should host avatars, not individual apps

fields.summary: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.atlassian.crowd.integration.authentication.ApplicationAuthenticationContext.<init>(Ljava/lang/String;Lcom/atlassian/crowd/integration/authentication/PasswordCredential;[Lcom/atlassian/crowd/integration/authentication/Valid

fields.description:
When using the *authenticatePrincipal* SOAP API the *PasswordCredential* object allows you to define if the password is already encrypted or not.

However, Crowd never checks the value returned by *PasswordCredential.isEncryptedCredential()* when comparing the user password against the one in the local Crowd database.

Currently, only plain text passwords are supported.

*Workaround:* to [run Crowd with SSL|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+Crowd+to+Work+with+SSL] and then use the SOAP APIs through a HTTPS URL. This will ensure that the plain text passwords will be encrypted.
fields.summary: Crowd ignores the isEncryptedCredential value when authenticating users

fields.description:
On the following page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+Resources#CrowdRESTResources-UserResource

/user 
/user?username=USERNAME

reference to Figure 1

But using a UserTemplateWithAttributes to perform 'addUser' or 'updateUser', no attributes are added to crowd. An explicit 'storeUserAttributes' is needed.

Either update the documentation or allow the functions to accept the attributes.
fields.summary: REST user actions suggests attribute functionality

fields.description:
Editing existing Delegated Authentication Directory will show error  "There was an error in updating the directory. Please check the fields to ensure all entries are valid." in the UI

Steps to replicate the problem:
# Create a *Delegated Authentication directories* in crowd
# Fill in all the information
# Test if Crowd is able to connect LDAP
# Save the directory
# Now edit the directory, you can try editing the URL for example:
{code}
URL: ldap://10.60.1.117:389/
{code}
change it to 
{code}
ldap://10.60.1.114:389/
{code}
# Now fill in back the Password and try to save.

\\
The above will result the following:
!ui_error.png|thumbnail!

Below if the http header of submitting the editing information in the Delegated Authentication Directory:
!changing_the_DN.png|thumbnail!



Below is the http header of submitting the newly created Delegated Authentication Directory information:
!save_connector.png|thumbnail!

*This does not happens in LDAP connectors*
fields.summary: Editing existing Delegated Authentication Directory will throw "There was an error in updating the directory. Please check the fields to ensure all entries are valid."

fields.description:

/rest/usermanagement/1/session?validate-password=false

The error message given is:
"The validated object is null"
fields.summary: Crowd SSO token resource to authenticate user without validating the password does not work

fields.description:
I am trying to log in to the crowd server, started by using 'atlas-run --product crowd --version 2.0.7' and getting a invalid password error. When I check the system output, I found the following:

INFO talledLocalContainer Caused by: com.atlassian.crowd.integration.exception.InvalidAuthorizationTokenException: The password in the application's crowd.properties file does not match the password in crowd. Application with invalid password: crowd

The only relevant material I was able to find is related to changing the password for the crowd console itself. The default database file includes the password, but it's of course encrypted, and I don't see any other user accounts. I have tried copying the admin's encrypted password into the crowd account insert statement and running, but no luck.

I am basically running this out of the box, so I am tempted to blame windows character encoding. I am a little surprised not to find any other material on this, but perhaps writing crowd plugins is not very popular and everyone uses a mac? I will try on my mac when I get home. I was able to run the tutorial successfully in jira and the refapp, but I can't even get into crowd...

Don Brown requested that I create a Crowd bug, in response to my forum post, or I would have probably done a support request first.

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=50046&tstart=0

Thanks!
fields.summary: Can't login to Crowd in plugin development environment
Convert and store null email values as empty string in the database during AD synchronisation

fields.description:
We are using the Apache-Crowd connector to authenticate users for HTTP content and Subverison. Crowd, SVN and Apache are running on the same Machine with this Apache config:

    ProxyPass         /crowd        http://localhost:8095/crowd
    ProxyPassReverse  /crowd        http://localhost:8095/crowd

    Alias /tools X:/Tools
    <Location /tools>
        Options Indexes
        AuthName crowd
        AuthType Basic
        PerlAuthenHandler Apache::CrowdAuth  
        PerlSetVar CrowdAppName tools
        PerlSetVar CrowdAppPassword tools
        PerlSetVar CrowdSOAPURL http://localhost:8095/crowd/services/SecurityServer  
        PerlAuthzHandler Apache::CrowdAuthz
        PerlSetVar CrowdAllowedGroups tools-users:r
        Require valid-user
    </Location>     


When somebody (accidently?) set the environment variable HTTP_PROXY on this machine, access to /tools was no longer possible. In the Apache logs, an error says that Perl/site/lib/Atlassian/Crowd.pm fails in line 60. This is where the SOAP request if given to the SOAP::LITE Perl Library. The SOAP Library checks for the environment variable HTTP_PROXY and sends the request to the HTTP Proxy - which cannot handle "http://localhost:8095/crowd/services/SecurityServer"
and so it return an error. As a result, the authentication for /tools will fail.

There are several ways to fix this. Atlassian could extend the auth plugin to analyze the parameter CrowdSOAPURL in details. Then make SOAP::LITE not use any proxy setting for requests to "http://127.0.0.1:12345/..." or "http://loclahost:12345/...". But I assume SOAP::LITE has no such configuration options. 

Thus it may come down to extending/fixing Perl's SOAP::LITE to handle this properly. Or use another SOAP library that can handle this. 

I have solved this for now by removing HTTP_PROXY from the environment variables and telling everybody never ever to do this again.
fields.summary: localhost and HTTP_PROXY environment variable

fields.description:
If you change the username of an LDAP/AD user and re-sync the cache the new username is not picked up. 

One needs to disable/enable caching or change the username in the databse.
fields.summary: AD caching mis-behaving if the username case is changed/renamed

fields.description: Sorting out every possible error message is a large amount of work, but lets at least distinguish between a misconfiguration (eg SSO domain or IP address set incorrectly) and an invalid username/password combination.
fields.summary: Distinguish between invalid login details and a misconfigured application when logging into Crowd console

fields.description:
TrustedProxyManager uses a PropertyManager to store the addresses of trusted proxies. However, a PropertyManager should only be used to store simple values.

A new DAO should be created to store the trusted proxies.
fields.summary: TrustedProxyManager should store addresses in its own DAO

fields.description:
Customer reported a broken link on [Crowd SOAP API Documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD012/SOAP+API]. Broken link reported: http://docs.atlassian.com/crowd/current/com/atlassian/crowd/integration/service/soap/server/SecurityServer.html

Tried other versions of the same documentation, the link is the same.
fields.summary: Broken link on Crowd SOAP API Documentation

fields.description:
Might be nice if Atlassian considered enhancing Crowd's concept of a user (assuming that is what is responsible for the default user schema via embedded Crowd in Confluence 3.5+ and other Atlassian apps? It might just be a wrapper, but still...) or enhance Confluence such that via API a plugin could register certain things as being something that might be appropriate to display publicly/privately on the user's profile page, such as a score (gamification of wiki contributions) based on ratings of content they authored, provide badges for number of pages created or use of macros, etc.

I know the "badges" and "gamification" thing is not new and this has probably been considered before, and the profile area in any Atlassian app is not well traversed by many, but this request for employee recognition is probably particularly popular these days (as an alternative/addition to financial compensation), so it might help draw more people to Atlassian's apps?

(See related request in Confluence forum [here|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257362327].)
fields.summary: Consider adding ability to register badges, score, etc. with Profile in Atlassian apps (gamification)
JDK 1.5 incompatibility

fields.description:
A user should be able to authenticate themselves as an admin user and perform application management tasks.

While [CWD-2169|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2169] implemented the minimal required for applications to connect to JAACS, it's still missing features such as reordering directory mappings, setting directory mapping permissions, and search.

The functionality in {{com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationManager}} should be covered.
fields.summary: Application Management REST API

fields.description: Dont' allow users to enter empty Trusted Proxies
fields.summary: Don't allow empty Trusted Proxies

fields.description:
We have not tested Crowd integration with Active Directory Application Mode (ADAM). However, ADAM and Active Directory share the same code base, LDAP interface and API. So ADAM should work with Crowd, following the same integration instructions as above. If you try it, we'd be interested to hear of your experiences.

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Microsoft+Active+Directory
fields.summary: Tracking Feedback for ADAM integration

fields.description:
SpringComponentModuleDescriptor, instead of relying on normal lifecycle of spring beans as managed by plugin framework, does manipulate its own spring context file.

One possible rationale behind would be that in crowd we want to explicitly control beans lifecycle. Although, that could be useful sometimes, it can pose later problems since it's not the standard way as expected from the plugin framework's perspective. If there is no obvious benefit out of the ability to control bean lifecycle, I suggest we should refrain from this pattern.

Don suggested that this might have been done in order to support certain plugin-1 plugins which might no longer be relevant.
fields.summary: Investigate the reason why SpringComponentModuleDescriptor needs to dynamically manipulate spring context file

fields.description: The current implementation caches whether a particular proxy server address is trusted in the form of a single element in the cache as a HashMap. This issue will refactor the trusted proxy code to store the result of whether a proxy server address is trusted as separate elements - making the solution more thread-safe.
fields.summary: Refactor TrustedProxyManager to store allowed proxies in a separate cache

fields.description:
We are rapidly deploying Crowd integrations across our enterprise and our stymied by the fact that each client must be provided with a unique Crowd application and password. Since we're restricting clients based on IP it would be desirable to be able to encrypt the password in the client crowd.properties setup or even have the option of a token/crumb style client authentication:

# Crowd server generates unique seed for each application created
# Crowd interface generates a unique token for a specific client based on that seed and the remote IP address

So now instead of providing an application name and password to the remote client, we just give them a token. If the remote IP is removed from Crowd the token becomes invalid. 

This abstraction is really critical for us in truly deploying Crowd in our very much locked down enterprise environment. Our enterprise information security guys would not like to see us making "passwords" available to our clients and it doesn't seem to be the right "fit" to be creating a unique application for every remote client when they're running the same "app" but they're all unique consumers.
fields.summary: Support authentication with API tokens for Crowd applications

fields.description:
[As documented in the Crowd 2.1 Upgrade Notes|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+2.1+Upgrade+Notes#Crowd2.1UpgradeNotes-ChangedAuthorisationBehaviourwhenMultipleDirectoriesareMappedtoanApplication], the username and group memberships for the user are always obtained from the same directory. Therefore the group memberships are not aggregated across directories any more.

Would be very useful to have this functionality back, through an UI option that would allow group memberships to be aggregated across directories.
fields.summary: Add option that would allow group memberships to be aggregated across directories again

fields.description:
https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/INTEGRATION/Integration+Platform+2.9

Upgrades:
 * Plugin Framework 2.7
 * SAL 2.4
 * REST 2.3

fields.description: On a machine with multiple IP address, Crowd does not necessarily use the IP address on which it is listening in order to make a connection to the database. It appears to choose the first IP address given to it by the Java network API.
fields.summary: Incorrect IP address used to make connection to database

fields.summary: Crowd upgrade creates null trusted proxy entry

fields.description:
XmlValidator is causing a dependency on Xalan for Apps using Crowd Embedded.
We would like to avoid this dependency.
fields.summary: Remove dependency on Xalan from Crowd Embedded.
Add unit tests for the Pony2 directory

fields.description: Getting the active directories for an Application object happens a lot. There should be a convenience method on the Application interface and it can be cached where appropriate.
fields.summary: Application should provide convenience method and cache the active Directories

fields.description: Replace {{ObjectNotFoundException}} usages that represent Application not found with a proper {{ApplicationNotFoundException}}.
fields.summary: Introduce ApplicationNotFoundException

fields.description:
User|Group|Membership|ApplicationNotFoundException exception should all subclass ObjectNotFoundException.

Though not strictly part of this work, ObjectNotFoundException should store the entity class and the identifier passed in, in the constructor. At the moment these parameters are only used to create the exception message.
fields.summary: *NotFoundException should subclass ObjectNotFoundException

fields.description:
Currently if a directory sync fails, the failure is logged, but there is no indication of a failed sync in the UI.

This can be quite confusing so we should display an error message if a sync has failed.

Possible scenarios for sync failing:
* Incorrect configuration (eg. typo in baseDN, bad username/password)
* LDAP server is down
* Timeout exceeded for long trees.
fields.summary: Give some sort of feedback in UI if sync fails

fields.description:
JIRA 4.3 will roll with Seraph 2.4.

Since Seraph 2.4 is not binary compatible with Seraph 2.3, we will need to roll a v24 package for our authenticators (and create a new module).

Once this is done, we will want to create build that tests SSO with JIRA 4.3 milestone and Crowd trunk.
fields.summary: Get Crowd SSO working with JIRA 4.3

fields.description:
Currently the remote API layers (SOAP, REST) check for valid group memberships through the {{TokenAuthenticationManager}}.

The logic should be moved from {{TokenAuthenticationManagerImpl}}. The distinction between authentication and authorisation should be maintained in ApplicationService.

Questions:
  * Should the ApplicationService be performing caching of the group membership checks?
fields.summary: Add ability in ApplicationService to check if a user is authorised to authenticate with an application

fields.description:
A bit worried about the LDAP connection pool code (in CrowdAdminServiceImpl):

* Firstly it seems that getSystemConnectionPoolProperties() could be called before the System Properties are initialised by getApplication().
* Secondly CrowdAdminServiceImpl.getApplication() lazily initialises the system properties but CrowdServiceImpl.getApplication() does not.

Was there a reason not to just eagerly initialise the SystemConnectionPoolProperties in the constructor?
Why are we setting System properties rather than just reading and merging with DB properties?
(Can this sometimes fail? eg with security settings)
fields.summary: Review the initialisation of LDAP Connection Pool settings in the system properties

fields.description: Add ability to disable users using the REST API.
fields.summary: Add ability to disable users using the REST API

fields.description: I`m using the RestClientCrowd for retrieving User details but the directoryId is never fetched, please add this to the user details. The User objects has the getDirectoryId() method this suggests that this should work.
fields.summary: REST User.getDirectoryId() always returns 0

fields.description:
Currently, our "LDAP read-only" configuration sets the UPDATE_USER permission on the Directory it creates. This is a serious bug -- it permits the LDAP read-only configuration to update users on the remote LDAP server, which is not correct. However, it is currently required so that attributes can be updated when using an LDAP read-only configuration in Confluence or JIRA.

To fix this, we need a new permission UPDATE_USER_ATTRIBUTE and UPDATE_GROUP_ATTRIBUTE so that the LDAP read-only configuration supports setting attributes on groups and users (which are always stored locally), but doesn't allow the users on the remote system to be modified.

From the CrowdService perspective, the following methods must check the new UPDATE_USER_ATTRIBUTE permissions instead of UPDATE_USER:

* setUserAttribute(User, String, String)
* setUserAttribute(User, String, Set<String>)
* removeUserAttribute(User, String)
* removeAllUserAttributes(User)

And the following methods must check the new UPDATE_GROUP_ATTRIBUTE permission instead of UPDATE_GROUP:

* setGroupAttribute(Group, String, String)
* setGroupAttribute(Group, String, Set<String>)
* removeGroupAttribute(Group, String)
* removeAllGroupAttributes(Group)

(One clarification needed - are RemoteCrowdDirectory attributes stored locally or remotely? Does this affect the permission checking for this method?)
fields.summary: Read-only LDAP isn't - need separate permissions UPDATE_USER_ATTRIBUTE, UPDATE_GROUP_ATTRIBUTE for setUserAttribute, setGroupAttribute and friends
CrowdService membership removal should not throw MembershipNotFoundException

fields.description: Need to create a new module specifically containing a new custom remote directory. The module will only be used during testing to attempt to load a custom remote directory.
fields.summary: Create integration test for custom remote directories

fields.description:
Authentication failures produce error messages that don't make sense:
{noformat}com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidAuthenticationException: Account with name <Unauthorized> failed to authenticate
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.throwError(RestExecutor.java:385)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestExecutor$MethodExecutor.andReceive(RestExecutor.java:264)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.rest.service.RestCrowdClient.searchUsers(RestCrowdClient.java:268)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.RemoteCrowdDirectory.searchUsers(RemoteCrowdDirectory.java:143)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.cache.RemoteDirectoryCacheRefresher.findAllRemoteUsers(RemoteDirectoryCacheRefresher.java:48)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.cache.RemoteDirectoryCacheRefresher.synchroniseAllUsers(RemoteDirectoryCacheRefresher.java:67)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.cache.AbstractCacheRefresher.synchroniseAll(AbstractCacheRefresher.java:34)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.synchroniseCache(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:528)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectorySynchroniserHelperImpl.synchronise(DirectorySynchroniserHelperImpl.java:74){noformat}
fields.summary: Http status code 401 not handled correctly in Crowd rest client

fields.description:
Currently ConnectionPoolProperties, SystemConnectionPoolProperties and DefaultConnectionPoolProperties live in the embedded-crowd module.

Move them to crowd-ldap as conneciton pool properites are ldap specific, not embcwd specific.
fields.summary: Move ConnectionPoolProperties stuff into crowd-ldap as it is not embcwd specific

fields.description: Package up the REST functional tests for JIRA.  Should ideally just be a JAR that JIRA will run to perform their REST functional tests.
fields.summary: Package the REST functional tests for JIRA

fields.description:
This is one of our exit criteria for JIRA as a Crowd server.

The test will bring up an instance of Confluence (latest 3.5 milestone), configure a RemoteCrowdDirectory pointing to JIRA. Confluence should now be able to use JIRA's user-base.
fields.summary: Functional test with Confluence pointing RemoteCrowdDirectory at JIRA

fields.description:
The issue is much like CONF-15163

From JDK 1.5 this class is inluded in the JDK, so there is no need to ship that class anymore with Crowd. The real problem here is that you can configure certain app servers like WebLogic to prefer loading classes from the web application, which is a good thing, but leads to the app server loading other classes in the javax.xml.namespace package using the app server class loader and only the QName class using the web app class loader. This gives you a LinkageError because the app server class loader doesn't allow classes for that package to be loaded from a different class loader.

The problems are in the files
 * stax-api-1.0.1.jar
 * xml-apis-1.3.03.jar
 * xbean-2.2.0.jar

For there libraries are new versions available without the javax.xml.* packages.

I ran into this problem because I wanted to connect to a SOAP webservice (via wsdl2java) in my Crowd Plugin I'm developing.
fields.summary: Crowd ships with a javax.xml.namespace.QName class

fields.description:
Since removing a user after the user has created a content in Confluence is not supported (in Confluence).

I think it's worth to create a warning in Crowd's documentation for such operation for Confluence: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Deleting+or+Deactivating+a+User
fields.summary: Add warning in Crowd documentation for removing user

fields.description:
Not only Crowd and the Subversion/Apache connector but all the Atlassian products could have files available in a *yum* repository.

This would make the upgrade easier and faster.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to be upgraded through yum

fields.description:
The Crowd REST plugin depends on crowd-server.

We need to work out what services the REST plugin depend on and split that out into a separate, lighter module that JIRA can depend on.

The following services require a No-op implementation for JIRA:
  * TokenAuthenticationManager
  * PropertyManager
  * ClientProperties
  * ForgottenLoginManager
fields.summary: Split crowd-server module so that the crowd-rest plugin can be dropped into JIRA

fields.description:
Building Crowd with Maven 3 fails at crowd-integration-saml for default-copy-bundled-dependencies.

While this doesn't affect the official build, other developers may be using the latest version and we should help migration.
fields.summary: Let Crowd build with Maven 3

fields.description: The CrowdService bean that will be exposed in JIRA and Confluence should be exposed in Crowd so that it's easier for plugin developers to write cross-product user-management plugins.
fields.summary: Expose the CrowdService in Crowd

fields.description:
Go through 'Add Application' and enter a connection URL with an IPv6 literal (e.g., http://[::1]:8080/). 'Resolve IP Address' fails to extract the address from the URL.

As a workaround, use a domain name that resolves to the same IP address.
fields.summary: Add Application's 'Resolve IP Address' fails with IPv6 literals

fields.description:
Crowd performs case-insensitive comparisons of user/group name by:
1) String.toLowerCase and comparing the lowercase values
2) String.compareToIgnoreCase

This is inconsistent and produces an ordering/equality based on the system locale.

We should to using a single form of normalising user/group names for case-insensitive comparison, for a specific locale:

{code}
String.toLowerCase(FIXED_LOCALE)
{code}

This method should be available on a util class. The FIXED_LOCALE should default to Locale.ENGLISH.

This affects equals, hashcode, compareTo and comparators for domain objects with case-insensitive/case-preserving name schemes.

If Crowd 2.1 users are on a system locale that's not compatible with Locale.ENGLISH, then:
1) They would be able to export their data to XML and re-import it, so the normalisation process happens in Locale.ENGLISH for Crowd 2.2
2) We could allow them to specify an override for the FIXED_LOCALE via a system property
fields.summary: Case-insensitive String comparison is not tied to a locale
